abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the FUNDESCOLA project is
            rated satisfactory. The outcomes of the Innovations in Basic
            Education and Northeast Basic Education (NEBE) projects are
            rated moderately satisfactory. The projects exceeded or
            surpassed most targets for physical inputs and training but
            it is not clear that the learning goals were met. The
            objectives of the two NEBE projects were focused towards
            central management improvements, and these had little or no
            impact on quality improvement. Due to design shortcomings,
            Bank performance for the FUNDESCOLA project, which was
            designed to target schools, was satisfactory. Borrower
            performance is rated satisfactory for all but the
            Innovations in Education project. A number of OED lessons
            are confirmed with these projects: 1) Attention should be
            paid to state, municipal, or even school management, and
            moreover, to classromm time. States and municipalities that
            are better off are more likely to take advantage of
            Bank-financed resources. The challenge is to emcourage the
            poorer ones to benefit as well. Decentralizing school
            managmeent is not a panacea: autonomy permits the poorest or
            least knowledgeable municipalities to fall behind, without
            much possibility for helping the residents. Classroom
            observations may be used as predictors of achievement: they
            can potentially provide feedback and promote improvements
            sooner than achievement tests. Students' health needs
            and problems must be addressed to optimize cognitive
            development and classroom learning.
